The sighs of my song wou'd you hear</br>The numbers that flow from my heart,</br>As faints in its progress the year,</br>My muse from her mirth must depart.</br>The joys of the sportsman, my friend,</br>When thunders the gun in the vale,</br>My sorrows can never unbend,</br>While cruelty sobs in the vale.

'Tis barbarous in man to defend</br>The stubble to rob of its plume;</br>Our moments more harmless to spend</br>We'll hasten away to the gloom,</br>Where shade over shade deepens down,</br>And leaves a soft carpet supply,</br>The groves ruffled into a frown,</br>Look russet and bare to the eye.

What tho' the soft offspring of sweets</br>No longer enamel the the walk,</br>We'll take our farewel of the seats</br>In softest convivial talk;</br>For thou with white innocence deck'd,</br>Engross'd every grace in thy smile,</br>Simplicity paid the respect,</br>And soften'd thy bosom of toil.

Altho' the dun swallows retire,</br>Revert from our leaf-sheading glades;</br>The beauties of ev'ning admire,</br>Admire her far-spreading shades.</br>E'er lov'd be the pastoral lay</br>Which Nature in Autumn commands,</br>Be honour'd the year's latest ray,</br>That beams o'er the brown-mantled land.

Remember, Clarissa, we stray'd</br>To Colin's beneficent dome,</br>Where Charity, sweet smiling maid,</br>Embellish'd the villager's room.</br>Mankind thy most general friend,</br>Fair seraph of domage divine!</br>We saw thee to Colin descend,</br>Who triumph'd in all that was thine.

We saw her all meek and serene,</br>His transport was Charity's own;</br>How sweetly celestial her mien!</br>Unwrinkled by Misery's frown!</br>By Colin the goddess caress'd,</br>The tear that was sad ceas'd to flow;</br>The pang of the soul was represt,</br>Tho' fixt by some despot of woe.

'Tis Nature, thy eve, let my steal</br>From all th' insensible crowd:</br>Clarissa, if finely you feel</br>My sentiment publish aloud:</br>And that the soft feelings are yours</br>Stands first on the page of my creed,</br>The thought sober Fancy ensures,</br>And brings to affection the lead.

The virgin, less bright than yourself,</br>Irradiates the fast-wasting week,</br>My prospect's unbounded by wealth,</br>Conceal not in public to speak;</br>Say sadness ne'er enter'd the grove,</br>Thin clad in the weeds of distress,</br>But Corydon's chearfully strove</br>To render Anxiety less.

Yet not too ambitious for praise,</br>Say when to the soft plaintive reed</br>Your shepherd a tribute wou'd raise</br>'Twas friendship alone was his meed.</br>Yet would ye believe it, ye swains,</br>That friendship was slow in return!</br>Ye maids who inhabit the plains,</br>That scorn at good nature to spurn?

Remember when Zanga applied,</br>Was Corydon deaf to his call?</br>Compassion untainted by pride,</br>Prevented approaching his fall!</br>And witness, thou moon, with thy light,</br>When mantled in silver thy mien,</br>Autumnus in stores to invite</br>On wains to the barn on the green.

Did zephyrs to Zanga reply</br>Yet lull not his breast to repose,</br>The streamlets all wept to his cry,</br>Yet heal'd not lamenting his woes;</br>Yet scarce had the sun to the west</br>Swept down the broad road of the day,</br>Than Corydon sought him distress'd,</br>The debt that he felt to repay.

Ingratitude sprung you from this?</br>O wonder not all that can know!</br>To man can his heart feel amiss,</br>Mistaken in healing of woe.</br>Nor wonder shou'd Verity say,</br>The child that is nurtur'd with care,</br>Forgets the fond hand to repay,</br>To whom kind returns would be dear.

But whither my muse wou'd you rove?</br>The ev'ning of autumn your song;</br>To Providence offer thy love,</br>For Providence never acts wrong;</br>Ask not to be wealthy nor great,</br>For trouble the twain will attend,</br>And wou'd you shun aggrandiz'd fate</br>Implicitly trust not a friend.

Lo!  spring, with her storehouse of joys,</br>To all the young pleasures gives birth</br>How soon ardent summer destroys</br>The season the sweetest on earth:</br>And summer to autumn must yield,</br>We cherish the peace of his eve,</br>'Tis gone — and thro' life's changing field</br>Thy winter, O Friendship!  we grieve.</br>
